content:
24, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a mars exploration game (duh) where you are the guy in charge of reseaching probes,rovers and other vehicles within a budget and then sending it to mars to gather information about the place and at the same time teach you,the player real life facts and events about mars itself.Its quite an interesting game if you're an avid space guy and wanna learn something new about mars and its moon.But i would like to say that this is a game that needs patience and tolerence,especially later on in the campaign because thats when the bigger,more complex machines like large rover are unlocked through research and i tell you the missions for those are long and ardous,especially since every part of the rover is so slow .So for me,it isnt uncommon to spend close to an hour to complete a mission and its major and minor ones.And maybe its just me but i cant find a fast forward button but even if there is one,i probably wont even be able to use it,the vehicles are fragile,so very fragile so constant attention has to be given so that  the rover dosnt veer off into some ditch like mine did.many times Its not fun to come back finding out its wheels came out just because it hit a little rock and yes its that fragile.So all in all,its a good game,it trains your nerves and patience,it teaches you stuff,the graphics are  pretty nice although it looks rough in some areas and its well made.One word of advice though, the drone of the rovers are very irritating in the long run so I recommend playing the game on mute.And get a weight to put on the keys if you're using a keyboard to play,theres no cruise control for the rover  as far as i know and theres no auto-pilot and dont even think about auto navigation, you know , like press a point and kaboom ,you get teleported there ,nope ,this is a simulation so my advice is to get a nice,good weight for the forward key at least.Oh and there are still some game-breaking bugs and glitchs in it so im going to wait for the full release before i touch it again.I suggest you do too to if you want enjoy the game without its stackoverflows and fatal errors.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
21, 2015
Early Access Review
								This simulation is outstanding. Unmanned (land + space) and manned sim, all in one.I'm outraged at some negative reviews written by people with 3 hours of game on record. Early access means opportunity to improve the game before final release, so use it, instead of ♥♥♥♥♥ing about it. Intellectual dishonesty is despicable, as is insulting the obvious hard work behind this project. And no, I-m not paid by anyone.The scientifc depth, the attention to realism, the gameplay, the graphics, everything testifies of the skills of the developing team, and their commitment to an ambitious and fascinating project. Kudos to them, also for their responsiveness to the community.I am about to finish the space program, therefore haven't nearly explored the whole scope of the game, not even tried the manned or survival part of it. But I can already confidently say that even only with what I have seen now, this is well worth the money. The BETA is stable. And it has the potential to be, simply, a masterpiece. If a number of recommendations and ideas as presented by the community will be integrated in the final development the game, it can IMHO attain a level of unprecedented excellence.Of course, this is not for adrenaline junkies. I process my mails, watch the news, and even manage some substantive discussion with my wife, while playing this (...). But if you are into realistic space exploration, astrophysics, astronautics, (space) engineering, then do yourself a favor and support this project. Devs, don't give up. I know people want space zombies and stuff, but I-m not the only one enjoying and appreciating the scientific (and fun) dimension of your project.Building my first large rover, landing it, navigating it through Martian terrain, and proceeding with a successful series of scientific tasks... that was freaking good.The Zero-gravity probe is great fun too. Here too, the experience is very immersive, the wannabe astronaut in me has a hard-on when navigating the asteroid belt and getting, after a careful approach (prepare to see your vehicle shattered by debris, or crashed by your recklessness), to scoop dirt and more, while zooming out in the big black space.  Highly, highly recommended.Current games: Silent Hunter 5 (heavily modded...), Verdun, and now ... Take on Mars.

content:
, 2016
Early Access Review
								After several failed attempts at docking with International Space Station (ISS), decided to just relax and let my ship auto dock. I sip my coffee, and watch the ports line up on my display. I raise an eyebrow. "Seems rather quick for an auto- JESUS CHRIST!" I swat at the manual override button, but it's useless. A loud bang and explosion of gas as my hull depressurizes. The cockpit canopy above me shears away, revealing a dizzying spectacle of swirling stars. On instinct alone, and in what could have only been a second or two, I release my harness and dive out through the gaping hole. A section of the craft snags my suit, tearing one of the legs. Still spinning. I see the solar panels of the station. Stars. Panels. Stars. I'm getting closer. I might just- Miss it completely. I close my eyes. I ponder how far I'll drift in 45 minutes before my oxygen runs out. Do I even have that long? I only know one thing... I'm dead. Twirling amidst the vacuum. Glancing at the blue sphere I occasionally catch from the corner of my eye. The ISS growing further away... did it mean anything? Any of it? No. Not now. Not for me. F--- it. I sigh as I begin disconnecting my helmet and fade further into the black.

content:
0, 2015
Early Access Review
								Take on Mars could easily become one of my favorite games if Bohemia takes it in the right direction. Currently, the singleplayer guidence is severly lacking. It teaches you about the different rooms within the faciliy, goes over the map, and finally gives you the option of using game time or real time. Thats it. I didn't get too far into the singleplayer experience but I would assume that theres no lessons on what to do once you land someone on the surface.(I do get that this is still being made)Multiplayer and scenarios (?) are super fun when they go well, but terrible when they dont. Singleplayer scenarios never crash (unlike their multiplayer counterparts) but lack the entertainment that another person brings. Multiplayer crashes often but can be so so so much fun. The physics engine seems a little wonk, so exploiting it in the mobile lab or on top of the flying lander is just plain goofy. Base building may need an update, right now you have to put every single panel in place by your self. There are no templates unless you are editing a world. Overall, this game is worth the money if:a) you have someone to play withb) you are willing to be patient and wait for the bugs to be hammered out

number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
19, 2016
Product received for free
Early Access Review
Take On Mars (TKOM), another entry in the "Take On" series by Bohemia Interactive, is one of the only games of its kind. It is a fairly realistic Mars mission simulator. It sports two modes: Space Program and regular singleplayer. Space Program is exactly as it sounds. You take control of a space agency of some sort, and you are tasked with completing missions involving exploration of the Martian surface, or even analysis with a small rover or lander. Your early endeavours will involve a lot of picture-taking and roaming the surface in search of more picturesque views to photograph and send back to the Earth. Regular singleplayer allows you to fast-forward a few years and actually walk on the red planet, which is essentially treated like a survival game, allowing you to build a base and grow food on the desolate surface of the planet Mars.Take On Mars is one of my personal favorite games. It looks great, plays well, and the experience is always different. All of the modes are really fun to play, and you have a lot of freedom in either scenario. You 3D-print pieces to make and personalize your base in human mode, and you can choose what equipment gets loaded onto your landers or rovers, like extra batteries, higher-powered antennae, or even nicer cameras. The game is still in development, with the release just on the Horizon (is that a Mars rover joke? I don't know. I don't keep up with that ♥♥♥♥).While I do love this game, I have to talk about performance. I said it "looks great." That's sort of a half-truth. I run a modest GTX 660 in combination with a Core2Quad that's always on its period and is more irritable than you would believe. Due to my budget-level setup, I get okay performance on okay settings. Luckily for me, the engine the game is built in has the most ridiculous graphic settings menu I've ever seen. On top of being able to change regular settings like anti-aliasing or SSAO, you can set the actual render resolution, which basically just renders everything at a level proportional (or equal, if you choose) to your screen resolution. I play in 1080p, but if I need to, I render at .9 times the resolution, or 1728x972, to get those extra frames. The most recent update added adaptive physics, because those can really kill your performance, especially when you build a big-♥♥♥ base for no reason. Hey, I can't blame you.ProsRealisticGood visualsGreat gameplayConsNo space travel, just ground or orbit scenariosSpotty performance on some machinesReally, really, really derpy player character modelFinal Thoughts:TKOM, even in its current state, is very playable and highly enjoyable for space-y types. It has a vibe similar to that of The Martian (starring Matt Damon, fantastic film, watch it if you haven't already) and plays however you want it to. If you like KSP, you might like the space program management gamemode, except you may be disappointed in the fact that you don't hand-craft your ships, hand-pick your crew, and personally control the flight. Otherwise, TKOM is a fantastic game well-worth the price, and it comes from a reputable dev that knows how to deliver a damn good game.Rating: 9/10This review was written for and is published on the  Lit Reviews [LR] curator page.

content:
4
												This game is awful in so many ways - and yet, I highly recommend it!The basic premise is to run a space program, explore Mars and other parts of our solar system, and if you play the campaign from start to finish, you start with Rovers and progress to manned missions. As the player you can very much scale the challenge to what you want to do - some missions require you to just move a camera, others need you to pilot a spacecraft in zero-g - and that is both as boring and as challenging as it sounds.The game tries to give you that Space Program feel, and there begins the problems. The interface is clunky, it's not explained at all, and there are any number of cutscens that just bore the crap out of you. Some of the challenges require a mindnumbing rover-drive for 1 km across mars - that gets really boring too, and feels like you're investing offline time for in-game progress. The game is just as unforgiving and buggy as all of Bohemia's products are. I've had two crafts fall through the ground on insertion, and since you're always kind of strapped for cash, that can cripple your program and force you to do some of those long drives or reload. The game - for some inexplicably bad design reason - doesn't autosave when you start a mission, so reloads can cost you if you forgot to constantly save.And yet, it is so much fun! The feeling of building a space program is very real and the challenges with bugs and the penalties for failure make you feel exposed to the elements like in a survival game. I've played a ton of Kerbal and I love the heck out of this experience, bugs aside.So really: give it a go if you love space exploration and strategy games.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
er 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								I can't understand, why people are so angry about a Early Access Game with some bugs and glitches. Yes, they are in the Game and maybe a long time, but I repeat: It's Early Access!!! The other thing is the way you play the Game. Myself, I had the patience to drive around a Rover for HOURS and I MEAN HOURS!!! You can adjust the speed to "realistic" but that is too slow, even for my kind of patience. For a "realistic" player, i must mention, that you can also give orders in form of timed console inputs, instead of driving a rover (or other craft) with the keys. I am bit over 40 Years old and can remember the steps of Mars Exploration from my Childhood until now, so for me, a dream came true, when I saw the Game in the Sale and decided to buy it now, even in EA-State, because I watched the Game for a long Time.I still enjoy it very, very much! I have a 4 year old PC and a 2 Year old Graphic Card, not the best, not the worst. The only lag i had was, when physics and graphics, for example in a sandstorm, came together. Then i noticed, the game becoming "clunky". Simple Trick: Save the Game, back to Game and it vanished and you can play another hour without disturbance. And I'm playing on max Graphic settings, so can't understand the problems of the other people here, having massive lags and graphic problems.As you watch my gametime, be advised, I'm still in the Robot-Exploration Phase, because I want to play the Campaign "My way" with discovering ALL Missions and earn lots of money. You may play the Game another way and that's also, what pleased me much: Do what you want, when you want, where you want and follow the path of Exploration, but: LOOK FOR HAZARDS!!! The sandstorms can kill your Rovers in short time, so seek shelter behind rocks or dunes, before the lenses of your cameras are so scratched, that you only can drive in 3rd person Mode. I love this realism! I love the way my Rover makes a "Salto" when i underestimated a small cliff. I love it, when Energy runs out, because i forgot, that the polar region is MUCH colder than the deserts and driving AND heating the Instruments need too much energy together.That leads me to another point: You always can save and load, WHEN you decided right at start, where the Game asks you, if you want to play realistic (no fast forward in Mission Control) or not. A crash? Ok, loading Game, once again. What  are the people expecting, when they play the "realistic" way??? Donuts and Coffee? Self steering, magic, landers, avoding obstacles and rocks for themselves? Red Carpet for your machines and a flat road leading to your exploration targets on the surface? Man, THIS IS A SIMULATION!!! Maybe realistic, maybe not, that depends of the player, but you have to LEARN, that Mars Exploration is a series of failures and crashes. Mr. Google can help you find out, what REAL Exploration is like. I am German and watched with great interest the actual Mars Probe of the ESA. What happened? Another unsuccessful Mission and a bit of very expensive hardware rotting in a Mars Desert! That's LIfe!Hey, i bought this Game, i can exploring the Mars myself and don't have to wait until ESA has success!

content:
22, 2016
Early Access Review
								--For those wanting to just get to a hands on review skip to the secondary section.--I have been watching and following, and in the past had time to help with hunting bugs and harassing the devs with copy pasted reports since it first came out on early access. Over time I have gotten to see this game grow more and more, thus expanding it's own potential. Take On Mars not only is a simulator, but an educational platform (Hence the wiki data you unlock in the Robotics portion.). With games like this, and Kerbal Space Program, I see a lot of potential for games to bring new challenges and focus to many forms of education in simulation that can even be utilized in classrooms to get kids interested in space exploration, physics, astrobiology, and aeronautics through adaptive and hands on learning.I know it's been a long time, and yes the due date has been pushed back, and yes there are still bugs that need to be smashed. But in the end, Take On Mars will be a perfect platform for both simulation lovers, and Mars Enthusiasts as the work put into this makes it one of the most unique games currently in beta. Long strides have been made in gaming technology that opens up more intuitive and complex forms of learning and adapting to in game demands through user comprehension and skill. This game needs as much notice and support as possible.------------------------------------------------Section Two--------------------------------------Take On Mars is a game based on the research of Mars in understanding what is to be expected for human crews to work with. In the first portion you are able to utilize probes, lander, rovers, and advanced equipment to study the martian surface and gather real world intel based on scientific findings. In chapter two you will take the role of a surviving astronaut who has to survive on the surface through building and maintaining equipment (Chapter2 is still in development.) Also there are singleplayer and multiplayer scenarios, along with an editor so that you can build your own scenario and upload it to the workshop. Along with this is the ability to easily mod the game files via the developer toolset if you're into that. This gives grounds so a lot of malleability to the game and what players can do with it. Overall, despite it being unfinished I have to give it a 8/10 for both the improvements, the dev team, and the uniqueness of the game. There are others sure, like Mars: Challenger, which is fun but not one I can honestly recommend. All in all, Take On Mars is a gem, and to those wondering if it is worth buying I will say this:If you don't mind putting in the effort to submit bug reports, push the game mechanics, and test different aspects of the game then yes, buy it and help the developers expand and debug more of it.If you want something polished off the bat and are not patient or willing to aid in development, then no, and nor should you buy any game on Early Access because that is what it is for.

The whole "Super realism" thing always gets me, and it is in space which is also super cool.But, when playing it I just felt like it had been through 0 play testing, and no one had tried to push the limits at all...For instance, durring the manned mission campaign you need an Oxygen Tank to pressurize your little tent in order to complete the mission. But I did not know this because it was my first play through. So, I tried to use the tank on my suit to get more Oxygen for my suit.However, it didn't work it just emptied it into the atmosphere. Then when the part where I needed to fill my tent up, I could no longer do it, it wouldn't even snap in place anymore.So, I thought it was the wrong item or something and spent the remaining 14minutes of oxygen I had looking for something else, but never did.Then once I figured out why it didn't work, I beat the mission and went to the lunar mission where it told me I needed to go south of the base to find supply drops, and that was all it told me.So, I started driving the buggy south (Which refueling the buggy was insanely difficult, it doesn't tell you how or what to do, left is empty, right one is fuel up spent maybe 10-15minutes messing around with it.)So, Im driving on the moon with my buggy when all the sudden I fall through the floor of the moon, and I am just now falling forever under the mission.I restart and walk up to my buggy and i get flung into space, the movement and physics engine is horrible. You can prop surf on accident very easily.As far as the robotics campaign goes, I am not sure, whenever I tried to do a mission and went back to the Mission Control room the screen was entirely black and I would have to restart  the game to fix it.It really just should not be out of Early Access, it feels like a game that shouldnt even be out of Pre-early access. There should still be lots of inhouse testing.i would not recommend in its current state.However, i feel if by some miracle they fix bugs, I feel like online multiplayer with some good mods might make for a really fun space survival game. IF IF, one can dream.

content:
r 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'm a fan of the survival genre. I'm a fan of the science-fiction genre. Put those two together and you get Take on Mars.While not completely finished, as denotes it's Beta Build, it is on it's way to becoming a remarkably accurate simulator (with obvious gameplay exceptions) of survival on Mars.That being said... it does suffer similar problems to most Open World Sandbox games of the same ilk at the moment. Notably the 'nothing to do but survive' problem. At least in most scenarios. Take On Mars, however, seems to address this problem with the Scenario / Scenario Editor... you can utilise triggers, events, etc. to create a story arc style of play. From landing, base building, to extraction should you want it, and thus solve the major issues of the survive to survive most survival genre titles have.What strikes me most about this game in either the Single or Multiplayer, is the emptiness. Some put it down as a Con, I put it down as a Pro... Mars is empty. There is very little to do there in reality, and this is refelcted somewhat by gameplay. However, the inclusion of science experiments, sampling, and more would add greatly to the overall experience. You can 'fake' science with the previously mentioned Scenario Triggers, but this pales in comparison to what the developers could possibly do in terms of story arc.Single Player - The Single Player Gameplay starts with what could be considered a 'modern space age' where you send probes, landers and rovers to Mars, Deimos, and even the Asteroid Belt. After 'completing' this portion of the campaign gathering all the outlined data under objectives, you are ready to launch your manned mission.I don't want to spoil the storyline of this mission arc, but Mark Watney move over, there's a new King of Mars. And it is story driven, though limited in scope. Starting in one area, and moving to another. With no option to alter which starting area, nor where you head to.If you're looking for a completely free-roam Open World Sandbox game, this one is not for you. If you're looking for a game that throws enough realism in your face to be accounted a 'true' survival game then this is the one for you.The team seems dedicated to keeping updates flowing, and they do address problems with the product as they can.The game has been in Early Access for a while, but this doesn't phase me in the slightest. Years in development is basically any title that has something unique about it, or needs to be built in a different way from previous titles. Comparing development times of a game like this to games such as Battlefield or Call of Duty wastes time, and mental energy. Building onto previously formulae (Battlefield, Call of Duty, <insert other franchise here>) will always be faster, easier, and more efficient than creating something new, and I prefer the effectiveness of Take On Mars to the fast development that would see it be a reskin of another title.In conclusion, the game does have bugs, and some of its elements lack polish, but if the development team continues the way they are going it may well show a new way to experience survival that actually throws whatever it can at you to make you fail, without big green aliens, zombies, or other post apocalyptic horrors.

content:
18, 2015
Early Access Review
								I wanted to love this game/simulation so very much, but unfortunatelly, this has been stuck in endless Early Access for far too long. Initially, the development team seems to have been taking their sweet time doing tiny updates to this title. After a year or so wasted, the development did pick up. However, lately, it's back into constant-postpone mode. The release date is actually no longer even specified and just says "at some point in 2015", even though not that long ago it was set to "june 2015". The game itself is quite fun and relaxing, you explore the surface of Mars, using vaguely realistic and progresively more modern technology. Over the course of development, other bodies were added and a manned program is now also available as a "cherry on top". However, bugs are a plenty, and the neverending development hell is what makes this not recomended to anyone, but the biggest fan. Once it's released and fixed up, it'll be an excellent title, worth the recomendation, however, in it's current state, such release is no longer even guaranteed.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
3, 2015
Early Access Review
								There's just something so calm and satisfying about driving on the surface of Mars for hours. You do some science stuff in the space program, building custom landers and rovers and researching new technologies to unlock new parts for your vehicles. There are plenty of locations available that are fairly big, so you won't run out of Mars surface to drive on anytime soon. There are also several scenarios in the game, some which enable you to play as an astronaut on Mars (and even on the Moon and in orbit!) and built bases and drive around in big cool rovers. I only played 6 hours as of this review, but I can already see that there's plenty more fun to be had here! So if you like things that have something to with space exploration, this is a must have game for you, in my opinion. Also, if you read The Martian by Andy Weir and liked it, you'll probably love this game too.

content:
1, 2014
Early Access Review
								I don't even have the words to describe how much I like this game...Or, you know, "game". Not sure if the word applies, but I'm going to use it anyway.Here's what you do: Send stuff to mars. On mars, you control stuff like the wheels on rovers, various cameras and scientific equipment etc. Everything is very slow-paced. You have specific missions that tell you to photograph certain features, test the atmosphere at a specific locations, etc. There are no enemies. There is very little challenge... Except it reuires a very specific type of mind to enjoy spending half an hour driving a tiny rover a few hundre meters of more or less featureless desert to take a few photographs, maybe a soil sample, then move on.Lately, more challenges have been added, which I really like. The tech tree wasn't there when I first began playing, and I enjoy trying to figure out what to research next in order to unlock the next batch of missions. It also feels like money is a bit tighter, which means a bit of budgeting and making sure you don't overextend. The vehicles run out of juice earlier as well, which means there's some challenge in trying to get as much use from each rover as possible, completing several missions before it gives up.Another kind of challenging thing is how easily things break. I've completed several missions with rovers that are missing two or more wheels (using well-known workarounds such as driving backwards)...The graphics are top notch aside from a few quirks (sometimes rocks still hover slightly above the landscape...)All in all an incredibly rewarding experience to the patient-minded who want a break from pvp and rts and fps...

Early Access Review
								I was not going to write a review on Take on Mars until it came out of Early Access but i feel i should. This game is a bit of a mixed bag for me and while i love the concept of this game i feel it could contain a lot more content. Take Multiplayer for instance, Once you have built your habitat? Nothing. There is simply nothing to do. Even collecting samples and analyzing them is too simple and gives you nothing for it. There are still a few bugs for me which hopefully should be gone by the time it goes full release. Singleplayer is another story though (forgive the pun). To me this was awesome, hands down just awesome, especially the recently introduced manned space program. Its like being in the movie martian. i would recommend buying this game just for the story. The other selling point for me personally is "who wouldn't want to go to mars?". So final verdict i give this 7 out of 10 for A originality and B just to take a concept like this and turn it into a full standalone game is worthy of praise. I will review it again after 9th feb when it goes out of EA.

content:
21
												First off let me state that I'm not the type of person to say "I told you so".But during this game's time in EA I kept stressing the fact that Bohemia Interactive missed several deadlines that they themselves assigned; even making a few posts on the Discussions board and leaving a few comments to warn people about what to expect. The responses I'd receive were in the field of, "It's Alpha just wait it'll be great!"Well now after several delays we're here and out of EA and while this game is an interesting concept it handles like hot garbage. Bugs bugs and more bugs. The controls are awful and getting anything built of worth is a slog through sticky muck.I enjoyed the concept of the single player campaign/story they added (ignoring that it mirrored the Martian almost completely, cause original story design is hard), but my enjoyment was hard fought after dying when I tried to lay down in the Poptent my first night, dying when I sat down in the Cargo Truck, dying when a canister I dropped into a cargo box ricocheted and slammed into my head (that was pretty funny despite the auto save being almost an hour old), and the worst of them all, me eating one of the ration packs erasing the progress I had on a previously completed objective making it impossible for me to actually finish the story. (Why the objectives don’t lock upon completion is anyone’s guess)On the subject of Multiplayer, why in the world does this game lack the ability to host Dedicated Servers? The Peer-2-Peer that they have in place now is god awful. I guess I can hope that eventually they’ll address this issue and release dedicated server files, but I’m not expecting much. So to wrap this up after all the delays and all the “It’ll be great” fan service what we’re left with is a game that feels unfinished and an overall sense that BI didn’t have the time to sit down and actually test their game from a playability standpoint. I’d say avoid at all costs unless it’s on sale for $5 and you really enjoy the concept of space games, even if this one explicitly does a bad job at most everything.

ry 14
												Well I was honestly hoping for them to fix the multitude of existing bugs before even considering a full release . Boy was I wrong , they went straight from bug ridden alpha to full release. That leads me to assume they gonna stop any and all development and move on. Sad as they game had potentiall but needed  the bugs fixed. Simple things like no rocket sounds on desent in landing in mp, tripping on a rock and flying 100 metre to your death, these have been around for far far too long and still not addressed. So many small bugs it hard to list them on the list goes on and on. Sad that they decided to push it to full release in its current state does not bode well for this game.Best part is does not matter what mp you choose coop or competive the landing craft nasa sends you down in is not radiation proteced. As if NASA would really be that stupid to send an astronaunt to mars and not shield his landing vehicle . Why even send us there to let us die before even leaving or landing craft makes really good sense way to go NASA.Hard to believe but it gets worse , major solar events every few minutes making it impossible to survive due to the total lack of any kind of radiation shielding provided . like really NASA would send ppl to mars knowing full well they would die of radtion exposure on day one HMMMMM something up with that. Not to mantion your astronaut is a total clumsey fool. falling and tripping over the slighest obstacle or even when brushing walls, would NASA really send a person to mars that uncoordinated, Thier a danger to themselves and everyone around. I get the feeling that somehow the research that went in the game was misguided or deliberately corrupted. In all honesty the game played better 6 months ago than it does now.Lets get real , true astronauts which  Nasa wold send to mars would be the best of the best , physically , mentally etc. They not gonna run out of breathe or have extreme heart rates after a few sec of exertion lol , they certainly not goona be majorly clumsy either  the current ingame representation is the exact opposite of who would be sent to mars. Unless of course you wanted a guarenteed failure of the mission.As an interesting side note appears certian member of the community have taken to using thier acess to Dram as a tool to attempt to silence the ppl they disaggree withOriginally posted by Caribcanuk:Reality is niether space x or nasa would ever send a person to mars knowing full well the instant they land they gonna recieve a lethal dose orf radition before even leaving the capsule. Who would send ppl to mars knowing full well the instant they land they dead in hours from radiation poisioning. The capsule has nothing that is in anyway effective , the coop capsule has shielding but the competive , thats a death sentance fisrt storm your radiated to the read level not the orange the RED , You stand outside or in the capsule you get the exact same dose , A buddy and myself tested it i , makes no difference inside or outside same dose . Guess game breaking bugs are too low on his list.

content:
y 13
Early Access Review
								Played this game on a friends computer and had to buy it for myself, so that's why my time played is low.  Summary:While this game does have it's bugs, and the physics system can be downright frustrating, this game is addictive and should be looked at by all survival game enthusiasts.  So far I'm loving it and with the modding and multiplayer features, especially the custom scenarios, it has alot of replayability potential.Long version:The campaign mode is broken up into two parts. The first half involves you sending unmanned probes and rovers to the mars surface to complete missions for money.  That money gets spent on purchasing new equipment to carry out those missions as well as the research required to build new devices.  You can customize the equipment you send to mars as well, and its possible to use the rovers to complete multiple missions if it is equipped properly.  To be honest, this part of the game bored me, and I didn't get past the first hour of dropping probes to map out different parts of mars. The second half of the campain mode is the manned storyline.  It includes voice acting (well done imho) and a cohesive storyline that parallels Andy Weir's "The Martian."  This part was fun and well paced.  It centered around a manned expedition to mars that goes completely wrong and you are left stranded.  You complete goals and gather supplies to survive and attempt to make it back home.  The final mission even gives you a 3d printer that you use to craft things with to complete some goals, and in my opinion, this is where the game was the most fun.  I encountered a few issues with the storyline getting stuck (cutscene transitions mostly), or goal completion not registering properly, but not often and nothing game breaking, and I'm sure those will get resolved by release.However, this game doesn't come without it's problems, as any game does.  The biggest problem is with the physics engine's collision detection.  Object seperation due to collision does not always resolve gracefully, and many times results in a violent seperation.  Too many times you will die from an object (or you) spazzing out trying to resolve a collision detection event resulting in your death, or objects will be sent flying off at great speeds.  Because of this, SAVE OFTEN as this game has no autosave function, and you could potentially lose hours worth of work to a buggy physics death.  As a developer, I realize that physics are important for realism, but sometimes there is a need to disable physics or fuse objects together for the sake of game stability.  For instance, grabbed items (in your hand) should not clip with the avatar, creating a "surfing" effect causing you to fly off into space.  Some of this might be fixable before release, but I imagine some of it might require some extensive changes to the core physics engine, thus we might be stuck with it.  Movement is slow which makes accomplishing tasks take longer than in most games, but that's part of the realism and completely intended, so I don't have a problem with it.  The modding system seems pretty powerful and already there are some interesting mods in the steam workshop, including scenarios for you to play that have unique environments, goals, and starting supplies.  Fun survival vs environment mechanics that is a refreshing change from the constant stream of zombie survivals.  Multiplayer:I've only played locally by myself on a LAN, so I can't really tell you much about net play.  From what I've read, it's buggy, but the devs are working on making it more stable.  It has two game modes, competitive and co-op, so that part is nice.Survival aspects:Resource gathering is done via powered machines that gather generic resources from the martian environment such as rock, dirt, and atmosphere.  These are then put into a refinery to be broken down into chemical compounds, as well as raw elements.  These resources are then used for crafting, vehicle fuel, and personal survival (oxygen and water).Crafting in this game uses a unique modular 3d printer system.  The 3d printer is capable of building most game objects, but larger objects need larger printers.  Upgrade to bigger printers by building the parts from the previous one and assembling the new one.  Habitats can be custom built through a modular part snapping system.  Crafting and resource gathering is fun, but after a while you might get sick of hauling tons of resource barrels around from place to place.  That's where mods help out (resource cables/digitized resource transport)Can't think of anything else, so if I missed something, feel free to comment.

content:
ry 16
												I like this game, specifically the manned portion of it. You really get to experience what it would be like on Mars.But I can't really recommend it.1. The manned portion is short, and rather disappointing. Storywise it was ok, but not great. Most of the manned portion mechanics are completely unused. You can build bases, but it's not at all needed. You can mine, but it's also not needed. It almost feels like they ran out of ideas or got sick of developing it..2. The game is buggy. Really buggy. You can accidently kill yourself at times by jumping and somehow getting launched into the air. You can stand on items and pick them up to find yourself surfing through the air. The atmosphere in your base can suddenly vanish, for no apparent reason, leaving you to asphyxiate because your suit ran out of air.3. It's poorly documented, making it very difficult to know how to do some things, ie pressurizing a base.4. The UI is not great. It's very easy to accidentally use the wrong refinery recipe. It's sometimes hard to see the displays on machines because you just view them as in game scenery rather than getting a display interface. It's sometimes hard to connect barrels to slots and the key needed changes depending on scenarios.The robotic portion of the game is ok, but it again is hard to work out what to do at times, and can be hard to meet objectives because it's either unclear how or buggy, though it's not clear which.If you are only interested in the manned portion, then you most likely will need to be playing multiplayer, because the campaign is brief.If you can tolerate all these issues, and the idea interests you, then you'll probably love the game, as I do, but as it is, it should not have left early access.

content:
ber 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								This Game is very fun to play. This style of game is simular to a Survival/ Exploration/ Science type game. Although its still in development, that does not hinder its already fun content. Play the campaign, play a single map, or maybe try to create your own adventure with the editor. With some luck you may even attempt to create your own map in the workbench tool from TKOM's Launcher.EDIT: For those who do not like this style of gameplay or the game in general, i must note that you are not obligated to by this game before it is finished. Early Access Games are ment to have the community help in the development of the game, not to give you a polished game from the get go.I have come to realize that some might not like my point of view on this game, and that is your right but to challenge someone based on your own opinion is not what is needed. Post your own review if you want to give potential buyers your POV.As for the Modability of this game, yes its modable but so are most games now adays. It allows the developers and industry to showcase those hidden talents of those who may not be able to develop their own game.This game is primarily a space agency simulator that has mars, the moon and a few astroids as it's goals atm. It also has a manned mission section to it, this is where most of the multiplayer aspect comes from.This game has good things and bad things about it. But most games also have this and they have been top award winning games. If you want to know the good and the bad of a game, seek a review that gives you the pros and cons. I like this game and as such the cons are minor to me if ive even encountered them at all.

content:
8, 2015
Early Access Review
								THIS IS A REVISED REVIEW - Where I have changed my rating from a Must Avoid to now ABSOLUTELY RECOMMEND - Must Buy & Try.  Bohemia has made great progress with all the updates, and I'm playing it again after almost a year away.I liked the concept of this game from the moment that I came across it in Early Access and bought it.  It's the kind of game that I wanted to like so much, and have played for enough hours to give it an honest chance.  As others have said, It is NOT intuitive.  So, you have to find your own way through it most of the time - but I don't fault it for that, and in fact kinda like figuring stuff out.  I'm a 'don't help me - let me figure it out on my own' guy anyway.  So now, the rest of the story...  I break TKOM down into two categories:1) Multi-Player - Let's be fair: Pass!  I didn't buy it for the multiplayer, and haven't ever launched that part once, so I'd refer you to other reviews for pros and cons on this part. Moving on...2) Solo Play is divided into two sections: - First, the "Space Program", where I was immediately bored silly by launching an endless string of probes around the various craters on Mars, and completing photo recon, atmosphere & soil testing, etc.  I'm not knocking it!  It just didn't do it for me, y'know?!  That said, I never had any issues with it, and it was stable - so, the "Space Program" just wasn't my kind of game, but you may like it fine.  Snore.....zzzzzzzzzzzz XD- Second, the "Scenarios" option.  This is the place where I spend my time.  In this mode you are on the surface and can harvest resources, build a base, and have free rein, and I now find this part absolutely fantastic.  The modding community is active with all sorts of new add-ons and new scenarios to try.  When it comes to base building, you have the original Outpost style that is fairly user friendly to build and looks really good.  But now, you also have a different style base option called Modular, and it opens up the ability to have more complex, multi-level bases.  With the original Outpost style, when you build a wall, floor, window, ceiling, whatever, it just requires lining up the one, single block and your DONE.  But, with the Modular base, OMG, for a single section of wall, you have three layers to build, exterior, interior, and a final finished skin for the interior.  Two things - a) personally I like the simplicity of the Outpost style, and much prefer the looks; b) The Modular can take hours to build a single room, even with the 3D printer right next to you and running non-stop.  It might be worth it to me if it looked better, but I thought it looked like a building from some Gulag prison colony on Mars xD.  That said, I'm sure it would go together in a snap in multi-player with a team working on it.  It's really just a matter of taste.(BTW - My earlier review detailed the frequency of crashes every 30 minutes during gameplay, and happily, that is a thing of the past - I now find the game quite stable.  Another annoying quirk of earlier version was that when your character exited a bunk, chair, anything, after resting, he would seem to bounce around the cabin as if Zero G, until he died of his injuries LOL - This issue has resolved in newer versions).  Also, in my initial (negative) review I DID SAY  that TKOM had phenomenal potential... and it has completely lived up to that, with all the great updates.  Good work Bohemia.  I would still like to see an auto-save feature built into the game, but manual saves work fine for now.I hope some of you found this helpful. Cheers.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
2015
Early Access Review
								This is a revised review, after many patches.The good:- Many diverse game modes. And I do mean very diverse. - Decent modding support and capabilities.- One of the few games that does give you that old "hard-SF" space vibe. Its a nerdy game abotu space, which feels very refreshign after 100s of "flashy" fiction games on the topiuc of space exploration.- A decent survival game with resource extracting and base building etc, somewhat minecraft-style, but more rigid and more serious.The bad:- The game's physics engine is rough around the edges. When it works its great (does  aphenomenal job of simulating very low gravity on the moon for example). But at times you find yourself tripping over a cable in earth or mars gravity and the physics engine glitches and sends you flying 10 meters into the sky. These sort of physics glitches are annoying.- Its a "take it slow" game, not everyone's cup of tea. This might appeal more to pleople who play simulator games than to those who prefer action games. Both the manned and unmanned parts of the game - Shady and inconsistent OS support, something I really need to complain about. When I purchased the game, the Bohemia Interactive site listed "Windows XP / Windows 7 / Vista" in the Reccomended settings.  Now on steam its just Windows 7 and Vista. XP support seems to have been silently dropped and I feel somewhat cheated, as I was not able to play the game for a long time until I upgraded my PC and got a new Windows.- Some of the textures look a bit dated, though it has to be said that nice lighting and post-processing does a great job at covering this up.

								As early in the piece as it is, I have to say this game has lots of potential. I say game, as much as Farm Simulator is a game as well. They pretty much share the same mantle of sandbox exploration and techincal process to achieve simple goals. No shooting anything but rocks, and expansive, visually sutunning landscapes to drink in.  If you're a fanboi of space exploration (the real kind, without the frickin' laser beams -  strike that. It DOES have laser beams) then this is pobably what you've been missing in your life. And BIS do some good games. The Arma series is still very popular, due to their encouragment of the modding community. And ToM is no exception. It's early access, so you can still have some input, and it's cheap. If you like Kerbal Space Program and looking to release your inner Planetary Scientist, then I recommend you pick up this title.

content:
y 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Take on Mars: The Real Mars Simulator...Yes the first thing that comes to mind when I play Take on Mars is Gran Turismo. The game is very realistic and beautifully presented. However just like Gran Turismo it does get a little repetitive after a while.The game is very well made. It is highly informative and gives you a good sense of experience in controlling a unmanned mission to Mars.When I played it for the first time I found it difficult to understand. But after couple of hours of clicking to find the right screens I began to understand the idea of the game. This does make the main game difficult to play. There is a tutorial which you will need to read. Also researching technology in the game is not clear and difficult to understand. I hope in time that they will fix this. In the mean time you will need to explore the game itself as well as the planet Mars to understand how it works. If you do lose patients with the main game there are many single missions which will keep you occupied. They are all great fun and very informative. If you enjoy exploring then this is the game for you. You will visit actual locations on Mars, using actual scientific equipment to unlock the knowledge and mysteries of the big red planet.Depending on your graphics card the detail is amazing. When exploring Mars you do feel very alone on this vast world. The highly detailed graphics and sound effects create a atmosphere which leaves you very isolated in the game.The controls are awkward but I believe that was on purpose to add to the realism of controlling a remote control vehicle across space.I do recommend this game but you will need to be a little patient at times on how to play it. The game is still in it early stages and the potential for this game is vast. I am personally hoping they add sci-fi missions like a manned mission to Mars or first contact with martians. At time of this review being submitted the developers are currently very active in listening to the players and improving the game.

content:
, 2015
Early Access Review
								Planetary exploration sim for egg heads. For as long as I can remember I have had a fascination with earths red neighbour. Since a child I have watched and read all about the various probes and landers sent to Mars.  Heard all the stories, myths and theories surrounding that place. It won't be long now when we will see a real possibility of a human stepping onto mars for the first time even if it will be a one way trip.  Take on Mars has really surprised me. I was expecting some kind of open world Mars exploration game but oh it is so much, much more than that. So far I haven't even set foot on the place. I am playing the campaign which means I start my journey right at the beginning with simple probes and black / white pictures.In this mode you literally live through the history of exploration on Mars. Each successful mission earns you money which you can then plough into research to create more advanced exploration vehicles. As you advance it opens up ever more complex missions for your landers to complete. The lander camera view and the rugged Martian landscape really make you feel like you are in mission control.  There are a ton of other things you can do in Take on Mars including scenarios and multiplayer. For less than £10 this early release is a real diamond in the rough. Its fairly stable and very playable. The sounds and visuals that accompany you on your adventure add to the atmosphere.Take on Mars is not going to be for everybody. Its certainly not fast paced and the only action will come in the form of technical disasters or your astronaut suit running out of oxygen. For me though it gives me a chance to do something I will never experience. Its a wonderful journey about what has been, what is now and what is coming in the near future.I hope the developers keep putting their love into this title because if they do it will be a superb finished product.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
18, 2014
Early Access Review
								Can't fault this game in any way really.It does exactly what it says on the tin and more besides.With the manned mission coming, it shows nothing but bigger and better things on the horizon.And the best thing of all is that I can honestly say this has been the best experience of early access development I have encountered ever.Mostly it's just an occasional update. Sometimes it's a game released as a tech demo and then the devs vanish with your cash. Other times they release a couple of tiny updates that do nothing much, then call the game finished.These guys have been incredible, with a huge amount of updates, constant feedback on the forums, both here and the bohemia forums.I have even had them add me as a friend, ask for my input personally, and seen my suggestions added within a day.I have had them reply to a problem I was having, email my save file to one of them (Dram, he is just the best, seriously, great developer for early access, he is into helping the community all the time), and had a patch released that fixes a problem that only I was having. He did that within 2 hours of me posting the topic on the steam forum.As for the game. If you have any interest in this kind of thing, then this is for you. It does exactly what you would expect, and it does it in such a way as to make you feel like you work for NASA, without having to learn all about rocket science and such to do so.This alongside kerbal space program show exactly how this kind of game is great for early access, when they have the right developer.I can't fault this game at all.The only thing is that I am itching for release now, to see how the finished product turns out. But with all the new things they keep announcing, it looks likely to be in early access for a while.But seeing as the early access experience here has been almost as enjoyable as the game itself, I don't see that as a terrible thing. I have been made to feel important, an integral part of the evolution of the game, right from the start. And their enthusiasm hasn't waned at all.Buy it, buy it now, even if just to support early access done right.

content:
2
												First off, yes this game has a few bugs but nothing game breaking, just frustrating at times. If you're looking for a serious astronaut simulator, this is your game. It brings to life the slow tediousness of working in a space suit ridiculously far from home. After completing the main storyline, I am happy with the time I spent and will be playing through the extra scenarios included and hopefully finding some extra content in the workshop.Some tips if you are jumping in:- Save often, particularly if you're about to go through the cargo truck airlock. In one instance I had removed my suit and was suddenly pushed through the ceilinig of the airlock where I suffocated quickly. Just save often.- If the 3D printer you build says it has incorrect/missing parts but you are absolutely sure it has everything; take it apart and rebuild it with the same parts. Also make sure you have 4 resource inputs, the picture in the datapad only shows 2.

The flying vehicle and helo need to be mods since there's no way those would ever be on the surface.  Everything else is pretty much science fact = Recommended!

content:
er 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								I Really like the game which on it's own really does not tell all that much. But the way it feels and even more what it can become is just great. But there it is... What it CAN become. Right now for my taste the building part has not been developed enough to be statisfying.What you can build is awesome but then it would be nice if it actually worked well... for example I spend the last four hours mapping out and building a base only too tear it all down again because it snapped wrong in place and it could not be finished since it was not airtight... which when you have your entire HUD filled with "LEAK" is something easilly missed.What also is a downsite for me is the fact that i have been killed more often by my building then by mars itself, try to take a step up the ladder and be stuck. use shift to run you suddenly become the flash and slam so hard in the wall your entire suit is torn too pieces. Building items that suddenly decide you are the badguy and shoot towards you like being fired from a catapult are also not that uncommen for me.And yet... I Reccomend this game and this is why:It is a challenge but one in one of the most beautifull and stunning enviroments I have ever seen with this amount of freedom. You can do as you like (within certain boundries) but it remains realistic. It is slow moving but it has a beauty to that as well... and no matter how frustrating it sometimes might be it is one hell of a feeling to be racing a scout buggy across the desserts of mars with your home made base sitting there amongst nothing.... a beautifull and creepy thing to behold and see.If you want a simple survival game you should pass... but for a game that is in my opinion unique and visually stunning however with still a way to go and you are up for a challange.... You will not regret it.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
y 25
Early Access Review
								So.. I played this game for about ten hours now... and I would say it has tremendous potential... but that is as far as I will go. Potential. While the robotics programme starts fo kinda slow, the manned programme throws into the deep end and does so in a very immersive way. You are actually afraid of running out of oxygen...Soo.. now for the other side of the medal. Bugs... everywhere... and the occasional probelm with the UI or generally how the  player interacts with the surroundings. Ramps are aparently a massive problem! You can not simply walk up a ramp. You'll get stuck and have to jump (and jumping is dangerous.. more on that later). Once I parked my vehicle on a slope so it was tipped slightly to one side. My character, always facing exactly 90 degrees from the ground would simply not fit through the now slanted (reliative to him) doorframe anymore.Another thing is buttons... you can't reliably press them... and in an enviroment with a LOT of buttons a characters button pressing skills should be considered essential.On the other hand when you are working with equipment that has a touchdisplay, simply stand in front of it and click on the screen... and that is really cool. So... I stopped playing after about 9 hours... because some of the bugs just made it too frustrating... I was trying to get into a vehicle over a ramp... got stuck... tried to jump.. aand I asume i clipped into something, was propelled towards the vehicle and upon the impact tore my suit and died... it had been a while since I last saved.... (no autosaves and no quicksaves make it really hard to keep on top of that).As for the robotics... I built my first rover launched it to a site somewhat close to the edge of the map... It missed its drop zone... by enough to entirely miss the map... and it just kept falling the distance numbers next to the site markes started growing bigger again after a while... and it just kept falling... and since I had spend my last few coins on that rover I was stuck...So in its current state I cannot really recommend the game... but If the devs iron out the most annoying of these bugs and glitches I think it can be a very interesting game. Let's hope for the official release!

content:
ry 12
												Take on Mars has evolved massively since I first bought it in 2013. Driving my rover in the Victoria Crater for the first time was jaw-dropping and I still get that same sensation whenever I return to the red planet.The game is a detailed simulation, focusing on the science, technology and management of a Mars space program. It is generally a slow-paced, thoughtful affair. Admittedly, I left the game alone for some time as I didn't want to spoil everything before the full release, so I've only dabbled slightly in the co-op / manned missions, but despite the feature-creep of survival elements, the game's focus still appears to be managing the budget and tech for scientific.Most negative reviews seem focused on bugs and stability, which I've never had much of an issue with (even in Early Access), but Bohemia interactive have a great reputation for supporting and updating their games for a long time, so I have faith that any issues will be solved soon.If you're a space buff and want to try your hand at believable missions at a fictional space agency in the vein of NASA / ESA / ROSCOSMOS / etc., this is exactly the game you've been looking for. However, if you're more interested in an extraterrestrial co-op survival experience, you should probably look elsewhere (Empyrion / Space Engineers are more likely better options).

content:
11, 2014
Early Access Review
								First off, I want to point out that the last line of this review explains how I feel the game should be turning out, in case developers ever read these things.Let me begin by saying what has left me most amazed. The simulation of the equipment is impressive. The way the camera views work is great.Next up, the tech tree is impressive, but the implimentation of time restraints isn't so impressive.Let's get into the bad things now. Time warp..... It's a little animation that has your desk bounce, flash, and heeeeey it's been a day! You don't get this feature if you choose to set up time to follow real life, but with how quickly you can burn through all the missions you'll probably play for a very short time, like I have.Right now, it's not so good. Lack of polish is to be expected from an early access game, but the lack of gameplay is where I get my (lack of) recommendation from.You launch a probe, you mess with it for two minutes, you destroy the probe because now it's useless. I'm certain Expedition One will improve on this. We don't need a game simulating rapid-fire deployment of mars probes and rovers, I believe we need a game where you're actually pioneering Mars habitation.

content:
ber 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								Take on Mars is a game where you try to be the pioneer of colonize Mars; but first you need to pass trough a Space Program Campaign. If you want to have a lot of fun hours you should buy this game: Campaign, survival, build, online multiplayer and so. (Con respecto al precio es barato para lo que te entrega este titulo.)

Early Access Review
								Great game, a little bit tedius but still good fun and relaxing. The tediuness is because is in early access and all the bugs, problems and item are not be fixed or implemented completely yet! But still is a very good game.The Primary Campain (Exploration) is complete but is a bit tedius for some players... Nearly everyone I spoke is waiting for the Manned Campain, and that means living on the Moon, Asteroids, in Orbit and Mars! The Tutorial is just ok, but is not fully clear how to do things, so for some players it may be a steap curve learning,I will raccomend this game for 2 reasons: First the beauty of living in space, orbit or planets, the second is the stunning effect you can see and ability to construct nearly everything you want!I will not raccomend this game for everyone, because it has no real continuous action, unless it is an scripted event. Let me explain in ditails: You can do almost everything, but the are moments where you cannot do nothing until the resources or event finish or trigger, like if you have set up your base and started the resources, sometimes the only thing you can do is do something that you really not need for the next mission or the one you are doing, like looking for more drops, that you cannot use at the end of a scenario to the next (Unless the devs change that in the final release).Still is great to see Bohemia Interactive have great ideas for games and have the guts to takle a game like this brilliantly!

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
Early Access Review
								Short version - Take On Mars is a AAA game being made by an indi publisher. As such it's still in Beta and probably will be for some time - if that's an issue for you, favorite it and be patient. It is however being crafted with more realism and simulation and depth than any other space game you've played since KSP. You're going to kick yourself if you're a fan of real space sim stuff and don't play this game. Longer version - It started focused on sending probes to Mars and the inherent complications and experiences you'd find in that. That's already a very rich, very complex experience and worth the money. There's a tech tree you need to unlock, upgrades, scaling missions and tech and challenges that are a fun game already. Pick a location (created from actual surface scan data from Mars. No ♥♥♥♥, it legit mapped from photos and heightmap data of the surface of Mars) and start figuring out what missions you can do with a single probe. Much like current space exploration you have to gauge the money and tools available to you to maximize your productivity on the surface. You'll find challenges of opportunity that provide additional income and so you need to plan for the unexpected while keeping in a manageable budget and resources. It's challenging in similar ways to Kerbal Space Program only focused on a far more realisitic experience rather than a somewhat fantastical one. The probe missions and content is a fun and challenging game and, again, worth the money. However the devs have recognized the demand for something more personal and have started laying the groundwork for manned missions to Mars. It's still simple and in a development state and has a long way to go. However the devs have shown with the content already created that they're dedicated and focused on making a deep, complex and challenging environment. That's going to take time and as the scope of the game has changed so has the development timeline. If you like what you see so far, pick it up. If you're concerned, then wishlist it and wait. If you're reading this review though then you're probably the sort of person intrigued by a realistic, challenging view of what exploring and even visiting Mars would be like, using actual mapping and images of the Martian surface and science we theoretically have today. If that's the case you're going to want this game sooner rather than later. If that's something you want then why settle for later rather than sooner? Game In Beta Note:Some people are concerned with the development pace of the game. Always a concern with indie titles and it's a legit concern. You don't want a game that's been abandoned. That's not this game though. Devs have been working steadily so far, it's just a lot to make for an indie studio and there's no way you can look at the content that's already in the game and not realize that when it is released it's going to be the best, most realistic sim you could really hope for. It is a sim by the way - simulation is the name of the game. From different weights, uses and limitations to different sorts of suits to limited uses in the tests you can run on your probes to deadly radiation bursts from the Sun that Mars' whisper thin atmosphere and lack of magnetic field don't protect you from. You want a quick and dirty survival shooter they're already out. You want a realistic sim that tracks your oxygen usage based on your physical exertion, you need to have some patience.....and if you want to survive on the Red Planet you're going to need to be patient.

content:
5
												A Letter I Wrote to the Dev Team..My name is Mike S. and I’m from Las Vegas Nevada.I recently got your game take on mars 02-2017 official release. I Purchased it from Steam, I never read any of the reviews nor did I play during game development, I based my Purchase on the funny official game trailer.While this game has bugs and is not fully polished, It is hands down absolutely the most fun I’ve had playing a game in this genre.I’m in my 50s and probably wont be around to see man land on Mars… Thanks to Bohemia Interactive, I did save Billions of dollars in funding, completely skipped Astronaut training and used my blank check to experience first hand what it may be like to land on mars and science the crap out of potato’s.I admit I jumped right in and started playing the manned missions, bypassing other choices.I am having a total blast playing the game,  Playing at night allows for a more immersive game play because your all alone just like in the game. Nothing is too easy and the game forces you to think things thru a bit or you Fail and Die, “Love It”. The land scape is beautiful, And I got to drive on the moon too, the ( Moon Dream ) portion was perfect timing in the beginning as hands on training for Mars, and really helped with story telling. Running around mars taking selfies with my PDA is just a blast that adds more to the game.. “ Look Mom here is my camp “ .Whether you are aware or not you just set the standard for games about landing on mars, which will be an icon game when we do. Thank you very much for making Take On Mars, You guys did a fantastic Job.Ps.. I haven’t even finished the game and ill gladly pay more if you polish the game up for Pc’s with higher end graphics cards Ill gladly purchase the Graphics Pack DLC for $8.99..  Ill also buy the DLC adding the decent to Mars from the orbiter showing what went wrong with the landing, for 6.99 ( I need to See what went wrong ) Throw in a really decent earth lift off ( a view of the astronauts with earths ground getting smaller in the background ), then to the space station, then leaving the station going to sleep and then waking up again for a short amount of play time as the crew is getting ready for the Mars landing. DLC.. $12.99.. Screw it :) , Just go for a triple AAA game remake ( More Story and Game play) Ill buy it $59.00

content:
ry 13
												What little of the game I've played, I've enjoyed. I've played a little bit of the unmanned chapter and nearly gotten up to unlocking landers. However, I have not been able to play any further than that because I cannot play the game any more. And not in the "I hate this game, it's literally unplayable!" (And you mean metaphorically there, not literallly.) sense, but in the "game will not run properly or at all" sense (the proper use of the word 'literal'). Since some time in the fall of last year, whenever I try to boot it up I get some sort of "illegal read" error. At the time, this didn't bother me too much. I did contact customer support, who promptly told me to try uninstalling and reinstalling, the thing that I had done at least six times previously of my own accord. Of course, this did not work. Then, the game was in beta so I assumed it was just a beta glitch and would get fixed eventually. After the full release, the game still will not run. That's a pretty serious bug to leave in a full release. I've also read elsewhere about the difficult physics, something I (un)fortunately have no personal experience with but is still significant. As much as I like the concept of the game and want to recommend it, right now I'd have to recommend against it.

Although, I am concerned for the fact it was released in 2013 and is still in it's beta mode. It has so much potential and needs to be finished, they should dedicate more money and time into completing this product. it would bring them a huge revenue, but also give gamers, and people fascinated with space exploration, an opportunity to enter the field and understand the reality of space and another planet. What adds to the excitement is that NASA will be sending humans to Mars hopefully by 2030. This is an excellent game with so much to do and I stand to support it. Do not judge it too quickly, buy it and play it.

Early Access Review
								So after all these years I decided to give this game one last chance and play Manned mission.I was playing RC2 which will be most likely the final version, neverheless no more major bugs will be eradicated by the time this releases.I simply cannot recommend it because of large amount of gamebreaking bugs and performance issues.From my last playthrough:On the moon it is rather easy to trip your buggy. When you do so, there is like 80 percent chance you wil die when trying to exit the buggy, because you fall trhough the moon. When this happened to me after 1 hour of playing and being in 2nd mission, then I painfully realized, there is no checkpoint or autosave function. My last save was from one month ago. OK. I had to restart whole manned  campaign.Then I had to follow transmiters to find second one. It is stated that transmiter is situated south from the base and I should follow that path. Very first transmiter is situated north of base however. I did not realize that and followed direction of the transmitter, going north instead of south. And after like 1 minute of driving I fell off a map... Moon just ended and I fell to the void and kept falling until I loaded saved game.After like 25 deaths I managed to enter 3rd mission. That was where I rage guitted.I had to load 25 units of water to the truck. UI is very clunky so it was a pain really.But I lowered stairs to the truck and planned to grab water packs from crates and bring them to the truck, put them on the foor of the truck and so on.Then I found out you cannot simply climb the stairs by walking. You get stuck.So I started jumping on those stairs... I flopped almost everytime, but I manegd to get there like 12 packs of water. Then I jumped, flopped and bashed my head and cracked helmet, died, and last save is stil on the moon! I forgot to save when starting 3rd mission.When the stairs are not walkable, how do I load or enter the truck while only possible options almost everytime kills you?This game is so broken, that I cannot recommend it to anyone, and I am afraid it is bound to the game engine, since these are the same bugs as were 2 years ago.

content:
y 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								this game is Great! 8 out 10.WARNING - do not play this game if you like action. There generlly is none unless you make a mistake in which case it can cost you plenty.When you fire up the single player mode you are given the option of robotics or manned campain.the robotics campaign is then further broken down into Quick Time or Real Time opions.for the robitics campain you are tasked with launching probes and exploring Mars. An extensive tech tree alows you to use funds raised by completing objectives to research improved systems and rovers, that allow you to perform more complicated research. Larger missions can raise more cash but it's easy to get into the situatuion where alll your money is riding on one mission, only for a random system failer to cause it to smash into the ground. especially with new tech. Driving around taking photo's and air samples makes up most of the early robotics game play with surface sampling and other tests entering  mid to late campain.Driving a rover is good fun but it is easy to underestimate the weather and/or terrain effects and end up trailing bits all over the place. When bad weather stikes you can hide behind a rock and just hope that the thing survives. Unlike real operatiors you have the option to swich to other probes at any time.The Manned campain is still under construction but is a planed to be a series of liked sinariospro's -  Very pretty even at low settings.  Realistic locations and effects  Punishing single player campaigns (robotic - and maned)con's -  Very SLOW paced.   low gravity enviroments punish rushed actions.  Robotics campain consists of doing the same thing over and over to raise funds.  realistic affects can lead to R.U.D. of your probes and rovers. (Rapid Unplaned Disasembaly).

content:
29
												First of all, I would like to say that this game is fun and had entertained me for hours.  I don't believe that this game was ready for release, however.  There are numerous things that need to be addressed in the current state, especially in multiplayer.  The story mode for manned took no time at all to beat, however, you can choose to stay on Mars and build your base and gather supplies until you wish to leave, but there wasn't a lot of challenge to the manned story.  I would recommend this game if it were still in the early stages of beta, but I don't think that I would be able to recommend the game in it's current state based on what I believe a final product should be.  If you want to fight through some bugs and do some online playing or just do the single player scenarios to occupy your time, I would recommend it.Again, I do enjoy the base building and playing the rover storyline, but I think they tried to rush the final product in the manned story mode and mulitplayer seems to still have a number of bugs that need squashed.  3.5 out of 5

content:
er 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								Again, Bohemia makes a game that is 90% of the way to being fun.  Much like Arma 2, the game is beyond awesome when it works. It has so much to offer, but is plauged by poor QA. For a game that is not released yet, it is on par, but due to my experience with their other titles, most of the bugs and glitches will not be fixed when it releases (prove me wrong please!).Things like no auto saves, coupled with irregular crashes causes some pretty frustrating "screw it, I just wasted 2 hours of my night, just to have the game crash as I completed building my 3D printer" moments. I sincerely hope that the bugs and the storyline issues (not having enough guidance on how to complete the objectives that have only one way of being completed) get addressed. Pros:Very detailed space sim with just about anything you can think of having on a mission to Mars.Very fun storyline.Cons:Tons of bugs. Like watching that Mars movie where there are actually millions of bugs that eat peoples' bodies, only they aren't supposed to be there and they aren't living creatues.No auto save! I get how it can add to the challange of some games, but not when there are so many random crashes.GUI performance issues such as screen flickering when there are tips being displayed.Lack of guidance for mission objectives. Example: The instructions to build a 3D printer are a 2D picture of a printer. You have to figure out how it goes together.
