number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'm not sure why this game has mixed reviews.  It's still in beta, people.  Does it crash?  Yes, but you can STILL progress and have a meaningful experience if you're patient and save often.  I can't speak for multiplayer at this point, but in the last week I've built a fully functional base by myself (I'm a fan of the manned missions) and was into full-fledged methane production (a very time-consuming compound to make in the game).It's worth your time if you're a space/science buff and are looking for an immersive space exploration experience.  With the way that development is going now, it seems like when the kinks are worked out of this game it could be a real-life simulation of survival on the red planet...if NASA ever develops space suits that can be put on/removed by one person. That's how immersive it is.  It doesn't just stop at Mars, either.  You can send rovers or conduct manned missions to asteroids, the moon of earth and the moons of Mars (Phobos and Deimos).  The devs have thought of everything and the attention to detail is fantastic.  I'm eager to see what will come in future updates and the anticipated v. 1.0 release. I highly recommend this game as long as the devs keep up the good work.

content:
4, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game has some promise, but right now it is just very shallow. There is not much here and it doesn't fell like more is on the way. This is how kerbal space program could have gone horribly wrong. There is a lot of unimportant stuff here that could be expanded upon, but not a lot of expanding upon the good ideas. The last update was in 2015, 2015! That is completely unnacceptable. Especially since there are multiplle different places in-game which say "New features in early 2016!" Well, it's june. We are half wat through 2016 and the devs didn't even bother to remove or update those messages. My last complaint is a technical one. I was using a radio thermal electric generator. It reduced to 3/4 it's original output after a very short period of time. Are you INSANE!? It even says plutonium-238 in-game an element with a half life of 88 years, not less than a day. My camera also seemed to break for no reason? Granted these may be in-game features due to weather conditions. But if they are it merely highlights another flaw in the game. It explains almost nothing to you. The only tutorial is for manned missions, which currently make up almost none of the game. This left me stranded trying to figure out how to ploay this game from the second I hit the launch button. The construction system is a well implemented idea, but again! There are almost no missions or playable parts of the game which utilize this feature. PLEASE! Devs, get it together and flesh out this game. Take a hint from KSP and improve your updates. If you are thinking of buying this game, don't, I can barely refer to this as a game. Wait until the features have been fleshed out and the game is a game. The developers should be ashamed for charging anyone to "play" this husk. I don't know if they will finish the game, but there is potential. This demo has all of the requirements to make an amazing game, they just need to try. Yes, this is really more of a demo. A paid demo promising updates, no doubt riding on the back of ksp's success. Steer clear until this demo becomes a game, if ever.

content:
21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Early Access Review (first impressions)Okay played very little the game is a kinda timeline experience of what it takes to get from launching early technology style probes that have little more than a camera attached to them, right the way across to sending man to mars.This review is based on very little experience but so far its inrtriguing rather than compelling, i have opted to use real time gameplay and my first batch of research takes between 2-10hrs meaning for the next two hours i have nothing to do beyond looking at the screen. literally !!the other time options allow you to fast forward the game, and...you can skip this stage and jump right into the manned missions, or play some preset kind of campaigns if you so wish, then come back to the campaign, you can also log of the game for the whole 10hrs (depending on time mode selected) and research will continue without your presence.so in the first few hours im bored, but interested to see whats in store !!i also ran through the training campaigns, and so i have witnessed a little of the crafting style aspects of the game which dont exactly win awards, its most certainly about the mars experience, than being a game of survival in my view at this point. for example most things can be made on a printer without the need of resources, which is just dull to be honest. im going to recommend at this stage because honeslty whilst not jumping around with excitment just yet, im really interested where this will head as development goes on and so forth. If your a complete space nutjob, im convinced you will love this like a nerd likes highgrades, adrenaline junkies not so much

content:
er 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								Before I purchased this game (before it became early access) there had been talk of VR support (Oculus).  Now we're at the end of the 2nd Oculus dev kit and consumer Oculus is only a few months away. The Take on mars developer has no interest in supporting VR and one of the devs has blamed Oculusvr for this: "Originally posted by Dram:Hey guys, I am unsure at this point about Vive, but the Oculus will certainly not be supported. Since the newest 0.6 drivers they removed DirectX 9 support. TKOM runs on DX9, which means we're out of luck.Just to clarify, they needed to make the move to better support direct to Rift mode, so I perfectly understand their move as being unavoidable. Pity though :)"  << The question is why a game still in development is using the outdated DX9 engine? DX11 has been around for a long time and we now have DX12.  I would say the problem isn't that oculus implemented direct-mode only but that Bohemia are developing their games on the outdated DX9 API.VR aside... the game as it stands is pretty dull.

Early Access Review
								I think it's cool that the devs are turning out updates to this pretty neat sim.  But what would really be helpful is a post or two now and then that explains what the updates contain.  Just enough high-level feedback to the community to help us understand how awesome the update(s) is that we are experiencing.  New features, bug fixes, support, etc...  things like that would help us gain a better appreciation for a sim we already know and enjoy.  Personally, I would like to know when the radiation is being addressed.  Will there be additional shielding we can construct to protect from radiation?  Will there be radiation sickness pills we can find or manufacture?  I'm sure there are many questions that fans of this sim have and are anxiously awaiting feedback from the devs.  I think the Devs are doing a great job, but a little blurb now and then to the community would be nice.

content:
er 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								The developers say this will be released in February, and I have no idea how they think that will be possible. The unmanned portion seems mostly complete, but the manned portion needs at least another year. It's full of bugs and glitches, there is absolutely no tutorial, explanation, or guide anywhere, and it's lacking a lot of immersion. The bugs range from being unable to attach a power cable properly to being flung across the Martian desert because you stood on said cable the wrong way. With no explanation in-game, on the walkthroughs through Steam, or on any forum for the game, every feature is hidden until you stumble across it and major components of the game are difficult to work out. It took me three hours to figure out how to assemble a structure, and I still have no clue what any of the various utilities do. The immersion problem is one they definitely won't fix, though, because they seem pretty happy with what they have: you can hear your astronaut's breath and heartbeat. All the time. Very loudly. Right in your ear. He also can't move any faster than a slow stroll, even on Earth, and can only run ten or twenty meters before getting winded. On the Moon, you would expect to do some cool Moon-style walking like in the NASA videos, but he just casually strolls from one place to another. I got to night-time on Mars (difficult because it's 1:1 timescale and there's no way to advance time, like sleeping or waiting) and expected some sort of awe inspiring view, but it was totally unimpressive. I was more impressed the first time I got a craft into orbit in Kerbal Space Program. I have the graphics all maxed out on a mobile GPU and I get 60 FPS - that means you're not trying hard enough.From my previous experiences with this developer, I know what to expect: a game with countless flaws that showed promise and is occasionally, for very short periods, brilliant. Arma was like that, Take On Helicopters was like that, and DayZ is like that. They're very ambitious, and that's admirable, but they have no tenacity, patience, or follow-through.If you get it on sale, like I did, you'll have a fun ten hours or so before deciding to just wait for the full release. But seeing as how they say that'll be in February, I'd say you should wait until the patch/update schedule has slowed a bit, because there should be a lot of them.

content:
25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Lots of potential but I can't recommend it yet. I know its early access, but I'll change this review as soon as it advances enough for me to recommend it.It's clunky, and its boring. I love realistic space games (KSP, Orbiter) and I understand slow-paced methodical gameplay, but this is different - its boredom without any real satisfaction or feeling of reward. The system for managing resources is INCREDIBLY tedious, and topped off with controls that can best be described as "butterfingers". Also the design for the lander and some of the vehicles are very unergonomic and kill the 'realistic mars mission' vibe for me. However, the design of the 'truck' rover and the scout rover are excellent. The 'campaign' if you will is more polished, but the waypoint system is very confusing and it is still for the most part unrewarding and just not fun. The game is very atmoshperic though - especially the dust storms. The camera effects are a nice touch, it feels very real and is remarkably well done.So overall, a lot of potential, but don't buy it yet. Its too clunky and boring, but hopefully that will change before its final release.

content:
5, 2015
Early Access Review
								I really wanted to like this game, but found the game was lacking, even for early access. The career mode has lots of missions, but so many of them are recycled. I would recommend the game if there would actually be a point in building. PROS: - Good potential - Physics worked much better than expected - It is fun, for a limited time.CONS: - Structure building is a pain. Even after getting used to the awkward rotation, constantly running back and forth from the "3D Printer" to the place where the part had to be was annoying. The parts are also very VERY specific in how they have to be placed together.  - Carrer mode is a horrible grind, so many of the missions are recyled, and many of them simply involve watching a static drone. And by that, I mean literally watching the drone's camera feed as it crashes to Mars. Mission complete. Now do that 15 times. - Many of the Scenarios are fun, and have interesting objectives. The issue is that there is no reward of any kind for completion, nothing at all. It just feels pointless.- For trying to be serious about Mars exploration, some of the features are ridiculous (weird vehicles). The game goes from trying to be really serious about realism, to being more fantasy.- There's just no point yet. I understand that it's early access, but there is no goal of the game.

content:
r 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								It really pains me to write a negative review of this game. The visuals are stunning, and it has the potiential to be a great game. Unfortunately, at this point in time, its not. Its full of annoying bugs.I've just spent the last hour playing the single player story line, started researching more advanced probes....then the game crashes, and its corrupted the entire save...gone. Won't be starting it again.The "base building" is so difficult to control in the scenario mode that I gave up and didn't bother any further. Its such a convoluted control system, and the parts are very hard to get aligned at just the right angle for them to snap together. This issue pretty much extends to the entirely of the control interaction within the game.In the early access version, over 75% of the tutorial videos are not accessable. This leaves the player to flounder around,and try to figure out what to do, and how. Surely, this is a rooky error?? Tutorial videos are there for a reason, so not having them is very counter productive.If all the issues were sorted out, it would be a very good game, but at this point, I think its £15 I would have rather spent on something else.

content:
, 2015
Early Access Review
								Early Access Review.I've currently got 24hrs+ on record of having played this. I haven't touched multiplayer and I probably won't either. The trailer looks really cool and it was that, that drew me to the game. Unfortunately after 24 hours of play I have yet to walk on mars. I am sat behind a desk sending probes, landers and rovers on missions. I'm going to be honest it's becoming dull. I thought the rover would add a little something extra, it does boredom. It moves so slow and you tend to have to travel hundreds of meters to your first point. Why? I don't know. the landing process is fairly surgical, so if it knows where I need to be stop putting the cross hundreds of meters away or put the missions on the landing map so I can choose where to land. i'm presuming more is yet to come but I repeat I have been playing this game for 24 hours. Please don't get me wrong. This game/simulator is very detailed and I appreciate the content. Unfortunately it's also becoming really boring. The best way I can sum up my thoughts on "Take on Mars" is... there's a note to say saved games may not be compatible with future updates. If I started it up and my saved game was incompatible. I would delete it and never play it again. I'm currently persevering through to hopefully get to the parts of the trailer that looked fun. If I had to play through 24 hours of mind numbing trundling across Mars. I would have to delete it.

content:
ber 21, 2013
Early Access Review
								Mars. A barren Planet with red sand and rocks. Sounds boring. But this fellow manages to get us wondering about life there and we want to know more about it's past and if intelligent life might have existed or even still exists on Mars. This game feeds your curiosity and let's you explore well known places of the planet like Victoria or Kaiser Crater. The simulation is of course not 100% realistic - otherwise you would need to wait 20 minutes after each command. But the graphics are awesome and you face the dangers and beauty of Mars. And it has mods. If you like KSP, you might like this one too. The developers are very dedicated and the game gets updates very often. Oh and it has a real time mode. With correct conversion of Earth to Mars time.

								OMG if you like technical and realistic to a point, this game is for you, TAKE THE TIME TO DO THE TRAINING COARSE , it makes all the difference, very very pretty game, eye watering stuff, I have a GTX 980 and i7 5960 8 core, runs perfect on it, and should, game is not a fast paced shoot em up, but a technical marvel, and really lets you appreciate the efforts humans must go through to do ANYTHING of our planet, It has some fantastic missions, the developers have really excelled in this area, using real NASA missions and shaping the missions around such, they have added KAOS, yes MaxWellSmart would be turning in his grave, if he had one, lol, Some kaotic events that make the game very interesting, lots of exploration, flying ships and other heavy equiptment, all alot of technical fun.Definately  recommend this game, much fun exploring stuff, very different in the way this game has been created, a unique look into the world of NASA and its astronaughts and the complexities of space travel.8 out of 10

content:
r 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								NOTE: This review does not apply to the multiplayer aspect of the game.This game sounds very attractive on paper, Sadly right now it's little more than a thematic tech demo. From a technical standpoint it's a great piece of software, but it's simply not engaging.Usually games, even though they might be hardcore (Orbiter, Dwarf Fortress, even KSP) make you feel rewarded when you achieve your goals. Even when those goals are self-imposed, you have a sense of achievement.Imagine setting out to land on Eve and take off in KSP, or gather enough diamonds in Minecraft to make yourself a full set of armor. The game knows nothing about your objectives, but it has built-in impedements that make you feel you are working for something, and the game is balanced in such a way that, the more crazy your objective, the more difficulties you will encounter. And besides that, you have different tools at your disposal, in a way that you feel you have the freedom to attack the problem from different angles.Take on Mars feels like you are just following a fixed list of steps (missions are exactly that actually) in order to put a checkbox in your to-do list and move to the next item. You have very little room to improvise or be clever about how you approach the missions, and the hardships you encounter are just not interesting nor really challenging.As someone who has spent hundreds of hours playing the hardcore space flight sim Orbiter I would never have imagined a game like this would bore me. But sadly it does.The research tree is very rich, and the mechanics of building and deploying vehicles are rock solid. Perhaps the problem is the game is too linear for a sandbox.I'd wait until the developers fulfilled their vision for the game completely before buying it. Wait and see mode.

content:
1, 2016
Early Access Review
								I wanted to like this game so much.  But I am already fed up with it after about an hour of just doing the training tutorials.I can't get past the basic game movement controls, inventory, etc.  Walking is hideously slow, sprinting makes you exhausted, and you get caught on items/objects/people/etc.  In your inventory, you have to "examine" items to see details about them.  (For example, I can quickly double-click to add water packs to my inventory, but to see whether they are full or empty? Right click on the individual ones, click "examine," and THEN it tells you if it's full.  Uh... no.)  I had to do the first part of the tutorial 3 times because it had so many bugs.  The first time, I interacted with a tutorial "quest marker" before I had actually put a tool in my inventory.  The only way to exit that section of the tutorial was to put the tool in my hand... but I had no tool yet... so there was no way to exit the screen.  Had to restart.  Then, the next time, I was putting water packs in my inventory.  I accidentally dumped one water pack on the ground.  But, again, in order to exit that specific part of the tutorial, I had to put THAT water pack from THAT slot in my inventory into a water machine.  Couldn't exit my inventory to pick up the water pack.  Had to restart again.Then, it took me 5 full minutes to get into a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ helicopter.  The tutorial said to use spacebar to jump in at a specific point (highlighted by a tutorial "quest marker").  Well, no manner of jumping, running and jumping, jumping while close, jumping while far away, etc. would get me in the damn helicopter.  The only way I could get in was to go around to the other side and enter in a different entrance, and even then I think it was a miracle, since I hovered in the air unexplicably for several seconds while trying to get in that doorway.  Then, in the next part of the tutorial, half of my time was spent trying to make sure my cursor was within the 5 pixels necessary to open the airlock button on multiple sets of doors (but not the "cycle airlock" button, which was right next to it).  Then, I was supposed to switch out fuel cells in a buggy, but taking them out and putting the new ones in apparently requires some kind of god-like precision using the rotate button... or something....Not to mention that, when you move your mouse to look around, your view moves hella-fast, but when you move your mouse in an inventory screen, the cursor lags slowly behind your movements.  There were no settings to change your mouse sensitivity, so you're stuck with it.Honestly, maybe this game is awesome.  But I have played a lot of 1st person games, and the mechanics of this one are so ponderous that it isn't even worth it to me to learn more and keep trying.  Maybe if I could get through the creeping walk, getting stuck on corners/container lids/etc., having to spend forever centering your cursor on little buttons, or spending minutes rotating fuel cells so that I can get them at the right angle to switch them out (so that I have enough fuel to take another 90 second jaunt in a buggy), I could get to the good stuff.  But it's too maddening, so I'm gonna go play something else.

r 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								I would not recommend this game yet, it has a long way to go. I am a big fan of open world creative games and this looked amazing but after playing it, it really gets frustrating. The big thing that takes away the fun is the building, I mean thats sort of a big part of open world creative games right? Building in this game is slow and I dont mean minivan slow we are talking rascle scooter up hill with a 500 pound person slow. you want to build a base, cool, go ahead, but it will take you years, you build it 1 block at a time and you can create 1 block at a time on your 3D printer, yes you can make several 3D printers to speed things up, but each makes 1 block at a time and it takes from 30 seconds to 5 minutes each create the blocks. Now lets say the base you want to make has a simple 1000 blocks, after some math you will realize you are better off building your own mars mission in your back yard with sticks. Once you have the block you want then the "fun" part of trying to get it to line up where you want it. People that say its not that bad, true there are worse games, but if you think its not that bad, walk across the room in thbe starter mission without sufficating, go ahead, I'll wait. THats a bug thats still there how long after early access relese?

It would be deciding between going to site A or site B. Which rock to inspect, whether to deviate from the mission plan and visit a rock that's 50 meters in the opposite direction or not.Not "drive around with your gamepad for a couple days and build moon bases while wearing a space suit."I don't know. This should've been two games, not one.

								probably the most broken game I have ever played (if you can call it playing). I understand it is early access (multiplayer) but the state it is in it should not be released at all. The campaign works fine, however God help you if try to play multiplayer because it will crash because "out of memory" when I have allocated 2gb of ram to take on mars alone, and have 20gb in all. If that doesnt happen then it will crash for some other reason. If you are lucky enough that it doesnt crash then you will end up getting killed doing anything from getting out of the seat in the capsule, getting out of vehicles, using the elevator in the capsule, or from using the beds (which ironically is how you heal your character). It seems they are more concerned with putting  content in the game than fixing old problems. Honostly I want it to be a good game but it doesnt work. The campaign works but it isnt finished. The analysis always says the same thing and the objective is always either: search the area for something scientifically interesting, take sample, or take a picture. Fantastic concept for a game and I love the realistic behavior. I just hope opon release it will be worth my money.

content:
er 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								While the basic idea of this game is terrific, the execution is lacking in major ways. I really hope the developers continue to shape the main aspects of this game, as the concept does have a lot of potential.The big issue in my point of view, and why I'd not recommend it at this time:Very linear gameplay, for an exploration game it lacks the "open world" feeling. This is immediately evident when you execute your first mission, you can see a rectangular plane of mars, your mission area, floating in the void of space, in the early descent phase.The career part is mission based, so instead of conducting free-form exploration, the player launches a vehicle to perform a very specific set of tasks.The first ten missions you will launch for example consist of nothing more than selecting a point on the map, launch the vehicle, look at the descent phase, wait for the "exploration accomplished" info to pop up, and immediately disconnect from the vehicle as the mission is done even before you touch down.The next couple of missions involve you actually waiting until touchdown, activate one instrument, and disconnect.The vehicle design suffers from similar issues, it is just way too linear. You basically select a chassis, stick some instruments in predefined slots, without any real freedom in design.I really want to like this game, and in fact I do not regret investing the 15 bucks as it might get somewhere someday, but at this time there simply does not come up any real fun playing this.

								While the basic idea of this game is terrific, the execution is lacking in major ways. I really hope the developers continue to shape the main aspects of this game, as the concept does have a lot of potential.The big issue in my point of view, and why I'd not recommend it at this time:Very linear gameplay, for an exploration game it lacks the "open world" feeling. This is immediately evident when you execute your first mission, you can see a rectangular plane of mars, your mission area, floating in the void of space, in the early descent phase.The career part is mission based, so instead of conducting free-form exploration, the player launches a vehicle to perform a very specific set of tasks.The first ten missions you will launch for example consist of nothing more than selecting a point on the map, launch the vehicle, look at the descent phase, wait for the "exploration accomplished" info to pop up, and immediately disconnect from the vehicle as the mission is done even before you touch down.The next couple of missions involve you actually waiting until touchdown, activate one instrument, and disconnect.The vehicle design suffers from similar issues, it is just way too linear. You basically select a chassis, stick some instruments in predefined slots, without any real freedom in design.I really want to like this game, and in fact I do not regret investing the 15 bucks as it might get somewhere someday, but at this time there simply does not come up any real fun playing this.

number of helpful: 2 of 12 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
y 8
Early Access Review
								Do not buy. Plays like a $5 pre-alpha to advert a kickstarter, nowhere close to a $22 "release candidate."These remarks apply to "Robotics" career.I bought this yesterday and binge played it for over 12 hours. I started with a Robotics career, I haven't touched the manned career that Manley showcased in his video that inspired me to purchase Take On Mars. - It's very easy to go down a path that leaves you with no more viable missions, and not enough money to progress down the tech tree to a point where the game spawns more missions.- the surface is littered with side missions, but you cannot just send a vehicle down to do them. You have to be seeing a big main mission to launch a vehicle at. - If you want a scarred forehead from slamming it into the keyboard, this is definitely the game for you.- I build my first rover after the third restart of a career (tech tree, and mentioned mission issue). Upon launch, the vehicle flipped radically and parts broke off as the chute deployed. (the player does not control maneuvering, it is scripted at this point). The rover free falls to the surface, crashing. This repeated six times with various builds to see if it was my fault. - Expect to spend six hours of play in your first career figuring out what not to do.- Expect to spend twelve hours of play in your second career, getting a little bit further, but hitting a similar block further on.- Expect to spend... no forget it. In summary, this game does not play like a "release candidate." I get the sense that Take On Mars is a money farming mission for the developer company to generate a new engine for their Armed Assault line, which desperately needs multi-core CPU and GPU support. Take On Mars could have been a fun title, but it's not a $22 experience. It is a frustrating series of dead ends, messed up careers, and buggy robot deployments. Avoid this title until is matures (it hasn't done so in three years). This title suffers from an obvious lack of QA work in terms of bug stomping and play "fun factor," something this company is notorious for. Even with their policy of de-centralizing testing, in other words, letting the community test it, this title has essentially been in community testing for over two years, and this resultant game is COMPLETELY UNSATISFACTORY.

Spend your money on hooker's and drugs, like the rest of us. Oh I'm sorry, I'm reviewing a game, not writing a column for Hustler.  Well, where to begin- I certainly know where to end, unlike the development of this game. A long time ago in a galaxy not really that far away, there was a team of people tasked with making a Mars survival game. They had ambition, they had passion, and they had Mtn. Dew. Somewhere down the bumpy as ♥♥♥♥ road they got so lost they couldn't find thier own ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.  If I had a dime for each time they missed a deadline (oh ♥♥♥♥ that rhymes) I'd have a lot of ♥♥♥♥ING DIMES! Almost enough to develop and finish this game myself.  I've said it before in the forums and I'll say it again. They will probably never finish this game. If they do, it will probably never be optimized, fixed, and polished. I was looking forward to this game for ages. I played it just enough to get a good feel for everything, and I have to say, it was really good. However, the constant failures cast a large impending shadow of doubt that this title was brushed under the rug like The Stomping Ground. Drippy ♥♥♥♥, soggy ♥♥♥♥, arid ♥♥♥♥, and biblical ♥♥♥♥. That's right I said it.

number of helpful: 8 of 32 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Hello Gentlemen, Just got Take On Mars by Bohemia Interactive, the early access is available for download on steam. Downloaded it, installed it and double clicked on play. Straight to the options menu and run in windowed mode and then changed my mind and put it back to full screen mode. The first screen that greets you is the Take On Mars menu with the usual game options and a spinning depiction of planet Mars. You can hold down the LMB and spin the planet around and see cool sounding names like - Syrtis Major and Elysium Planitia. A few clicks and the initial tutorial loads up.  Clicked on Real World Time and eventually I make my way to the Lab and Construction Building. Found myself pressing the 'Test Vehicle' panel & see the lander. I see different views and instruments, You see (not manipulate) the outside world. My first test ship wobbled like crazy and the wide angle and telephoto view quality, looked like they had purchased the same cameras used in the Blair Witch project. Maybe it's an early alpha thing? I think Bohemia are simulating the quality of video/pictures sent from Mars back to Earth -- lossy and crap. Like any man on the planet who has never read an instruction manual since making 1/32 Airfix models, I end up pressing every single key to see what screens pop up. Oooh... aaarghhh... what does that do... oohhh.... Esc key goes to Main Menu.  Yawn and fast forwarded to the Launch vehicle 13mins 39secs. Look around the crater for about six or seven minutes and then stumble on the list of tasks required to be completed in this particular mission.After pressing every key again, q,w,e,r,t,y,,,,,. I find myself at the Capture Gas stage. oooh... aarghhhh.... Click on Capture Gas. Yay! DO NOT MOVE INSTRUMENT in flashing red text. First you capture the gas, then you analyse gas. (Insert Fart Joke) This is one of the Major Tasks completed at the initial first assignment Victoria Crater. Your initial foray in the Victoria Crater teaches you Mars atmospheric pressure differences compared to Earth and also the composition percentages of CO2, N & Ar (I knew learning the first twenty elements of the periodic table would be useful in my lifetime.. thanks to my grade 10 science teacher Mr Clewett). Once you complete a mission, you also get access to New Tech Levels and various vehicle and instruments at tech level 2 become available.  And I got a steam achievement unlocked "It's All About the Science" I then read the rest of the Mission task and see there is another minor task, a photo opportunity requirement.The light bulb dims and I figure out that mission tasks are comprised of Major task and Minor tasks. Each successful completion of Major & Minor tasks during a mission will allow you access to higher level tech and more cash to spend on stuff. In the Early Access version, I can see some instruments have power levels and charge / drain rates and I guess that there would be that certain tasks that require balancing energy usage from your chemical batteries before they are depleted in the later missions. Don't know yet if there are ways to recharge. It's interesting but not for everyone. Interesting enough I had the game freeze on me twice and waited and waited and waited.... before the three finger salute Ctrl+Alt+Del restarted the game.My initial thoughts coming from a Flight Sim enthusiast...... Well just like there are people that are vegetarians and there are people who like a medium rare wagyu rump with a side of hand cut fries, mushrooms swimming in a red wine jus. Take On Mars just doesn't have enough meat to satisfy me. Do your own due diligence and make an informed decision. Read the reviews, watch other videos and then make a purchase or not decision. I 'm not satisfied. If I want a space sim, Kerbal Space Program has that creativity streak that Take On Mars doesn't. Would I play Take On Mars often? Only if my Warthog HOTAS was stolen, and every other computer game I owned was destroyed and it was raining outside and it was a Saturday in June. Aside from that, sure I will play it.Another thing, what is early access, an alpha, beta or in-between? Call it what it is - an Alpha....Thanks go to my grade 10 Science teacher Mr Clewett -- You were right, I would use the knowledge of the first twenty elements in the periodic table in my life time. :)Score: 2/10

content:
30, 2014
Early Access Review
								This was a positive review, but I no longer feel that way. Ammended review:It's been in Early Access for (literally) years now. At some point it becomes an excuse for developers to never finish something, or always be able to promise "more features in the future" - which is what's happened here. I was severely disappointed several months ago when I realized they no longer cared about science results and testing of Mars and started focusing on the multiplayer aspect, but I know teenagers/gamers are the target audience on Steam, so I wasn't completely surprised by the shift. However, that was nearly a year ago. In that time, nothing has changed in the single-player "science" campaign at all. It's been the same thing since I bought the game years ago. I really, really wanted to like this game, but it's just not meant to be. I mean, how long can you call something "beta", yet make money from it, and get away with it?If Bohemia can own up to the failures and shortcomings and put some TLC (ie. patching, time, development, and customer concern awareness) back into this, I might switch back to a positive review. But that is very doubtful at this point. They've run out of time for me.

content:
y 10
												UPDATE:Now that the game is offically launched I can say the bugs are still there if not multiplied.  After the 2nd update since release none of my save work from the previous patch.  I enter my saves with all my structures blasting apart into pieces.  If I try to launch one of the built-in campaigns I am instantly dead.  I am going to have to give this game a "DO NOT BUY" until it is somewhat stable.ORIGINAL POST:First it should be said that this is NOT a released game and is still being developed.  The negative reviewers here cite issues like performance, audio sync issues, etc.  Fine tuning and optimization is one of the LAST steps in game development so you should expect performance and audio issues.  To walk into this game and expect every aspect that is in the game to be fully polished is an expectation that will not be achieved.The idea of Early access is to help the developers make a better game, not to submit negative reviews for items you should be alerting them about instead.  Be constuctive not destructive.  If you are not willing to accept bugs, performance problems, missing content or compatibility problems, then do not play an "Early Access" game.So far what i have seen of the Manned mission, it is a Mars survival game. You crashed, you need to get air, and a temporary shelter.  Then you go off and try to find better resources and build better ways to survive, all the while trying to find or build that piece of equipment that will save you and get you home.  If that is not your cup of tea, leave now, this is not for you.  If you are looking for big green aliens to shoot, look elswhere.  If you are looking for cutting edge graphics or horizons of breathtaking vistas, this is Mars, its rocky, red and dusty.This is about one man fighting to survive on Mars.
